captions.text:
Thank you, Mr Secretary General, your excellencies,
ladies and gentleman, and distinguished guests.

I’m honored to be here today, I stand before
you not as an expert but as a concerned citizen,

one of the 400,000 people who marched in the
streets of New York on Sunday, and the billions

of others around the world who want to solve
our climate crisis.

As an actor I pretend for a living. I play
fictitious characters often solving fictitious
problems.

I believe humankind has looked at climate
change in that same way: as if it were a fiction,

happening to someone else’s planet, as if
pretending that climate change wasn’t real
would somehow make it go away.

But I think we know better than that. Every
week, we’re seeing new and undeniable climate

events, evidence that accelerated climate
change is here now. We know that droughts

are intensifying, our oceans are warming and
acidifying, with methane plumes rising up

from beneath the ocean floor. We are seeing
extreme weather events, increased temperatures,

and the West Antarctic and Greenland ice-sheets
melting at unprecedented rates, decades ahead
of scientific projections.

None of this is rhetoric, and none of it is
hysteria. It is fact. The scientific community

knows it, Industry and governments know it,
even the United States military knows it.

The chief of the US navy’s Pacific command,
admiral Samuel Locklear, recently said that

climate change is our single greatest security
threat.

My Friends, this body – perhaps more than
any other gathering in human history – now

faces that difficult task. You can make history
... or be vilified by it.

To be clear, this is not about just telling
people to change their light bulbs or to buy

a hybrid car. This disaster has grown BEYOND
the choices that individuals make. This is

now about our industries, and governments
around the world taking decisive, large-scale
action.

I am not a scientist, but I don’t need to
be. Because the world’s scientific community

has spoken, and they have given us our prognosis,
if we do not act together, we will surely
perish.
Now is our moment for action.

We need to put a price tag on carbon emissions,
and eliminate government subsidies for coal,

gas, and oil companies. We need to end the
free ride that industrial polluters have been

given in the name of a free-market economy,
they don’t deserve our tax dollars, they

deserve our scrutiny. For the economy itself
will die if our ecosystems collapse.

The good news is that renewable energy is
not only achievable but good economic policy.

New research shows that by 2050 clean, renewable
energy could supply 100% of the world’s

energy needs using existing technologies,
and it would create millions of jobs.

This is not a partisan debate; it is a human
one. Clean air and water, and a livable climate

are inalienable human rights. And solving
this crisis is not a question of politics.

It is our moral obligation – if, admittedly,
a daunting one.

We only get one planet. Humankind must become
accountable on a massive scale for the wanton

destruction of our collective home. Protecting
our future on this planet depends on the conscious
evolution of our species.

This is the most urgent of times, and the
most urgent of messages.

Honored delegates, leaders of the world, I
pretend for a living. But you do not. The

people made their voices heard on Sunday around
the world and the momentum will not stop.

And now it’s YOUR turn, the time to answer
the greatest challenge of our existence on
this planet ... is now.

I beg you to face it with courage. And honesty.
Thank you.

title: Leonardo DiCaprio's 2014 UN Climate Summit Speech

drop-out.

While Climate Change may be real and not hysteria, the solutions proposed 
by DiCaprio, Gore, et al, are unrealistic and would harm millions of people 
around the world. We need solutions, but not the ones proposed by DiCaprio. 
Interestingly, the solutions proposed by DiCaprio are identical to the 
early anti-Capitalist environmentalists, before they had "science" to 
support their demands. Climate Change social activism is a case of science 
being created to support a social movement and political philosophy.  

The earth is always changing. Slight changes in the environment are always

comments.text:
This is exactly what irritates about the Hollywood political left.... 
DiCaprio was invited to go speak at the U.N.? Why? It isn't that his 
opinions are not important, they are. No one invited me to go speak at the 
U.N. Or, the man or woman down the street who works at the bank. The U.N. 
didn't invite YOU.  What is it about Leonardo DiCaprio that somehow makes 
him more qualified on this subject than... YOU? Why are DiCaprio's views 
treated as more important, more valid, more credible, more revered.... than 
mine? No one invited me to go speak at the U.N. And they didn't invite you 
either. ﻿
comments.author: Bobby Vaught

comments.text:
+045Tanya Yes, Tanya, you are correct. Reagan was an actor. With all due 
respect, that really misses my point. I never once remotely implied that 
entertainers couldn't have something credible to say. It is interesting 
that you brought up Reagan because the first election in which I was 
eligible to vote was November 1980. I voted for Reagan then and again in 
November 1984. However, I didn't give Reagan any MORE, or for that matter, 
any LESS credibility because he was an entertainer. Just as I didn't give 
Carter any more, or less, credibility because he was a farmer. We shouldn't 
make assumptions regarding causation. I didn't vote for Reagan BECAUSE he 
was an actor. I'm not that mindless. I voted for him because I happened 
to agreed with him more than I agreed with Carter (or in 1984, Mondale).
comments.author: Bobby Vaught

comments.text: +Ryan Wright Wasn't Reagan an actor at one time?
comments.author: 045Tanya

comments.text:
+Ryan Wright Thank you. By the way, no, I don't agree with DiCaprio on

comments.author: Bobby Vaught

comments.text:
well it seems to me like i read your issue wrong. we are in more agreement 
than i had thought. your problem seems to be aimed more at society. 

nothing makes him more qualified, but that doesn't mean he isn't more 
influential. i understand that you have a problem with people being more 
influenced by an entertainer than you or I, but that's just the way things 
are. 

and to clarify, i wasn't calling you a part of the mindless masses. i'm 
sure you can agree that there are a lot of dumb people out there who don't 
use their brain as much as they should
comments.author: Ryan Wright

comments.text:
+Ryan Wright Your post is built on a false premise... that I "have an issue 
with his qualification to speak on the topic" That is totally NOT what I 
wrote.  In fact, I would be more than happy to meet DiCaprio for coffee at 
Denny's and we could both speak about the topic as long as he wants. What I 
actually wrote was....

"It isn't that his (DiCaprio's) opinions are not important, THEY ARE" 
(emphasis added). And later in the same post I wrote, "What is it about 
Leonardo DiCaprio that somehow makes him MORE qualified..." (emphasis 
added).

And later in a different post but on this same thread I wrote, "what makes 
Leonardo DiCaprio MORE qualified to speak the U.N. than for example, ... 
myself? Or You?"

And in another post on this same thread what I actually wrote was, "why 
are entertainers views of the world treated as something to be MORE revered 
and honored than are my views... or yours?" (emphasis added)

In other words, I never once remotely questioned DiCaprio's qualification 
as a "concerned citizen." (that was the qualification that DiCaprio gave). 
I am a "concerned citizen," so are you. My question is why does society 
give entertainers a forum that the rest of us don't get? Why are 
entertainers views to be MORE revered than the rest of us?  

You wrote the following, " He (DiCaprio) will clearly influence more 
minds...." Followed by your points about how many views this video has. 
Really? Well, maybe some people are MORE influenced by an entertainer, I'm 
not, and I don't know any reason someone else should be either. Name one 
logical reason anyone should be MORE "influenced" by entertainers speaking 
their views versus... my neighbor for example.  

When entertainers express themselves in a forum the rest of us don't 
typically get, over and over, and OVER, it starts to come across as very 
professorial. That is especially true when they aren't really debating the 
issues, but merely making a speech (and there is a difference). Or, like 
when they get on some talk show and the host starts throwing them 
softballs. That isn't "debating" anything. So, when entertainers do things 
like that it comes across like they are saying, "hey, listen to ME, I make 
movies." Or, "hey, listen to ME, I can sing." They don't actually say that, 
but that is how we feel about it. Let's face it, DiCaprio did NOT get 
to speak at the U.N. because, as he put it, he is a "concerned citizen." I 
am a concerned citizen, if that is the qualification, well.. invite me 
then. DiCaprio was invited because he is in movies. Does that make him MORE 
qualified than me? or you? or your neighbor? Oh, yes, and the other reason 
DiCaprio was invited, as you pointed out, because he can donate "millions 
to the cause."

Oh, and I almost forgot... because he can, as you put it, "convince the 
mindless masses on what needs to be done." Gee, how elitist can a person 
possibly get? I wonder if DiCaprio thinks of the "masses". as 
"mindless." That isn't an accusation, I guess we would have to ask him. So, 
just to clarify.. me, my neighbor, the guy in my town who works at the oil 
refinery, etc.... we are just the "mindless masses" whereas DiCaprio has it 
all figured out? Really??? And his qualification for having it all figured 
out over us "mindless masses" is that he is in movies??? Or was it that he 
is a "concerned citizen" (as though the rest of us are not?). 

In any event, I didn't question DiCapario's qualification to speak on the 
topic. He could speak on the topic in the same forums I get, like coffee at 
Denny's for example. Better yet, I could make a good speech on the subject 
and DiCaprio could just sit and listen and not say anything. It seems to me 
that's what he expects the whole world to do for HIM. I didn't question 
DiCaprio's qualification to "speak on the topic" (your words). My question 
was what makes him MORE qualified to speak AT THE U.N.?
comments.author: Bobby Vaught

comments.text:
+Bobby Vaught I understand that you have an issue with his qualification to 
speak on the topic.. but why? Do your views conflict his? Or would you have 
preferred a scientist to be speaking on such issues? 

Because in the end, many more people are going to listen to what a 
"superstar" has to say rather than what a no name scientist or you and I 
has to say. And if Leo knows this, and a so called expert scientist knows 
this... why not just let Leo give the speech? He will clearly influence 
more minds and be more comfortable delivering a speech. And just for some 
numbers to help support my claim... this video has 500k views, and another 
video of the same thing on youtube has 2 million views. That proves that it 
is a video that people are going to watch and consider. If i was giving the 
speech I wouldn't get nearly those numbers. 

I guess my concern with your post is that you aren't asking what I think 
are the right questions. I'm glad that Leo is a great speech giver with a 
determination to fix climate change, because i know he will do what i can't 
and help convince the mindless masses on what needs to be done.. Soooo... 
whats the problem?
comments.author: Ryan Wright

comments.text:
+Ryan Wright (Apologies if this is similar to posts made in response to 
"Valkyrie editing" but I am having to respond to two different people here) 
I  am really not clear from that post where you stand on DiCaprio's so 
called qualifications.... your words, " maybe because you haven't donated 
millions to the cause like he has." I have no way of knowing whether that 
was meant to make a "pointed" point . Or whether you are saying that his 
donations do in fact somehow make him more qualified than you or me. In any 
event, THAT WASN'T THE QUALIFICATION TO SPEAK AT THE U.N. THAT DICAPRIO 
GAVE. HE said his qualification was that he is a "concerned citizen."    
 He could have said, "I am qualified to speak on this subject because I 
give 'millions to the cause'."     If giving "millions to the cause" is the 
qualification, then why didn't DiCaprio just say THAT?  The 
qualification that HE gave was, that he is a "concerned citizen." So we are 
back to my question that started the whole discussion . I am a concerned 
citizen. So are you. So why was DiCaprio invited to speak at the U.N. 
instead of me... or you? Why are entertainers views of the world treated as 
something to be more revered and honored than are my views... or yours?
comments.author: Bobby Vaught

comments.text:
+Valkyrie Editing By the way, the qualification that DiCaprio gave HIMSELF 
had nothing to do with being a "benefactor." The qualification HE gave was 
that he is a "concerned citizen.' (Like the rest of us are not?). If being 
a "benefactor of numerous organizations" was DiCaprio's qualification for 
speaking at the U.N., how come HE didn't say that?
comments.author: Bobby Vaught

comments.text:
+Valkyrie Editing By the way, since I am on a roll... DiCaprio is a 
"benefactor" to the cause? Okay, so excuse me for asking the obvious 
questions but, how much was it? What are a couple of the "numerous 
organizations" that he contributed to? I have a larger point about that but 
maybe I should let you answer those questions first.
comments.author: Bobby Vaught

comments.text:
+Valkyrie Editing I see. A "benefactor?" Really? THAT'S what somehow makes 
someone more qualified to speak at the U.N. because of how much money he 
can give? Really? So, just to clarify, because DiCaprio can give larger 
sums of money than most other people, he is now more qualified to speak on 
global climate change?In all fairness, if that's true then he does put his 
money where his mouth is. But, that hardly qualifies to KNOW more things 
about the world. By that standard, Bill Gates or Warren Buffet would know 
millions of times more than you or I. I have heard all kinds of "more 
credible than thou" tactics.... "I'm older than you are,"..."I took a class 
in that".... "I have a degree in that"... etc. I always handle it this way 
when in a discussion (the specific issue not material to the point), handle 
it this way.... "Okay, so you and I disagree on the issue (whatever it is) 
and you have more education than I do on the subject so you should have no 
trouble refuting my point. My point was... (then just restate whatever the 
point was on the issue being discussed)." In other words, keep the person 
on issue. And now I can add to the "more credible than thou" tactics... 
which people just happen to be the biggest benefactors. Geez.   

Okay, fine then....

Well, I am not just a financial analyst/portfolio manager. I am ALSO a ... 
how did you put it? Oh yeah, I am ALSO  a social advocate for change 
on multiple platforms as well as a benefactor of numerous organizations 
working to combat the problems of which I speak. That's what makes ME 
qualified because that is what I do when I am not working. Now, my question 
was... what makes Leonardo DiCaprio MORE qualified to speak the U.N. than 
for example, ... myself? Or You?

Here is another example. I was watching Letterman some years ago and one of 
his guests was Neil Young. Young took the time to speak to no end about his 
views of the world (or what he thinks the world should be). Fine. But in 
the same show there was a fireman (I think it was a fireman, it has been 
some years so I may be a bit shaky on the details of this story) it was 
someone who had done some heroic thing. Letterman didn't ask THAT person 
about HIS views of the world. I remember seeing that show years ago and 
thinking, "well why not David? You asked Neil Young!" Granted, that person 
was on the show NOT to express his views of the world but because he had 
done some heroic thing. It's also true than Neil Young wouldn't have been 
on the show if he couldn't play the guitar and sing. What made Neil Young 
more qualified that Letterman asked HIM about his views of the world, but 
not the later guest? NOTHING.

Look, I am not the only one who feels this way. I have had this very 
discussion with many other people. I spent my whole life studying and 
living MANY issues. Economic issues and many other things. One thing 
I about my life that I noticed about four years ago that I had never really 
thought of before. See if you can relate... I spend about half my life 
listening to what other people THINK. That happens when I go to church, 
when I turn on the television, numerous other things. The other half of my 
life is people valuing me for things I can DO. And there is a big 
difference. Look at the emails you get from people you don't know. I get a 
bunch of them. Everyone one of them values me for something I can do. Buy 
something, usually. THEY don't ask me what I think about anything. You 
understand WHY I and many others resent "Hollywood" being given conduits 
for what they think that the rest of us don't have? 

By the way, just for the record, I would have spoken at the U.N., if 
anything, significantly better than DiCaprio did. I wouldn't have needed a 
teleprompter. At most I would have had just an index card in my palm with a 
few bullet point notes on it of points I wanted to cover. That is the way I 
gave every other speech I ever made.    

One of the things people like about this high tech, youtube, information 
age is... you ARE media. Or, at least part of it. Like this post for 
example. At least it's something. But they still didn't invite me to speak 
at the U.N. did they? Nor you.

So, "Valkyrie editing".... what do you think?
comments.author: Bobby Vaught

comments.text: maybe because you haven't donated millions to the cause like he has.
comments.author: Ryan Wright

comments.text:

comments.author: Ka Boom

comments.text:
Boy using the oldest  trick in  the book should seem obvious but today's 
generation is ignorant to any propaganda tactics.. They think  they live in 
an unplanned world.. The reality: there is literally zero  evidence to show 
accelerated warming.. The temperature has been steadily rising since the 
last ice age.. Listen to the scientists directly -- not some actor with 
zero scientific background.. We all know pollution is bad. The 
irresponsible disposal of waste that is harmful to the environment.. But 
making "carbon" the enemy is ludicrous. Should we all hold our breath 
throughout the day  to cut back  on carbon emissions as well? The science 
on carbon emissions is blurry at best. Here is what the other reality is - 
there is a coal fired power plant about twenty miles from me.. The cleanest 
air in  the country but Obama's literal hostile economic tactics will now 
remove 80 million dollars and thousands of jobs from the area. He wasn't 
lying when he said - "you can build a coal fired power plant - we will just 
make it impossible for you to stay in business." Forty percent of our 
electricity comes from coal. Seventy percent from fossil fuels. If ever 
there was a President who did not want our economy to thrive - or become 
energy independent - meaning we do not need to rely on other countries - it 
is this President. Stop looking at the Hollywood popular thought and look 
at  the realities of the situation.. When  you graduate -  you no longer 
have that job as an opportunity. Unless you want to live in a dark, 
economically depressed america - keep supporting nonsense Hollywood 
"popular" thought.  This is why Leo is picked. The powers that be literally 
need to make this belief popular irregardless of the evidence.  Do you 
think China is going to stop? America will be in the gutter while China 
thrives..  America no longer produces steel, we no longer manufacture 
anything..  how can you be so willfully blind?﻿
comments.author: LordSendMeAnAngel3

comments.text:
Simple to understand, yet responsibility repudiated and thinking clouded by 
immediate, superficial certainties and tactical choices, rather than 
assessment based on honest appraisal of our past follies. For far too long, 
the developed world, led by the US, have set double standards in dealing 
with environmental issues, insofar as conveniently ignoring their 
historical emissions while passing on the burden of jointly controlling 
emissions with India. How can India, who contribute less than one-fiftieth 
per capita emissions compared to the US and that too only in the last 3 
decades, be subjected to the same strictures for containing pollution when 
her populations are tens of times poorer, and needs some freedom from the 
binding legislation in order to survive and develop??﻿
